root_title: Historia de la Medicina: medicina de los pueblos arcaicos extinguidos. La medicina en Mesopotamia
body:
Hoy sigo con esta serie de posts que he dedicado a la historia de la medicina ([inicio de la serie aquí](https://steemit.com/spanish/@eleyda78/historia-de-la-medicina-medicina-prehistorica)), continuando con el estudio de las “culturas arcaicas”. Llamamos “culturas arcaicas” a aquellas que partieron de las formas superiores de la cultura primitiva y que iniciaron la historia, es decir, iniciaron la etapa que podemos reconstruir a través de documentos escritos.
![Inicial español.jpg](https://steemitimages.com/DQmTES4ecyEbPijfBuGBodKShPSWQ6xV93sF3Dg3F1y8c9q/Inicial%20espa%C3%B1ol.jpg)
[Fuente](https://sobrehistoria.com/la-ciencia-en-mesopotamia/)
Existieron muchas culturas arcaicas, pero trataremos de dividirlas en dos grupos: aquellas que tras haber alcanzado un gran desarrollo y esplendor se extinguieron por completo, como los sumerios, asirios, los pueblos de Babilonia, Egipto y el antiguo Irán y aquellos que han perdurado hasta la actualidad como China, India antigua, Israel, Japón y pueblos de la América precolombina. En este post voy a hablarles de la historia de la medicina correspondiente a las culturas arcaicas extinguidas, empezando por la medicina mesopotámica. **LA MEDICINA EN MESOPOTAMIA: SUMERIA-ASIRIA-BABILONIA** Mesopotamia, zona geográfica que se encuentra entre los ríos Tigris y Éufrates, ha sido escenarios de varias culturas ya extinguidas: la sumeria, la acadia, la asiría, la babilónica. Las primerias ciudades sumerias aparecen hacia el año 4.000 a.C y a partir de allí, alcanzan un desarrollo a lo largo de tres milenios y medio, hasta que el imperio babilónico es destruidos por los persas hacia el año 539 a.C. (estaba mayormente ubicado en lo que hoy corresponde a Irak).
![mapa.jpg](https://steemitimages.com/500x500/https://steemitimages.com/DQmawxtoiS6jTpWhusaYfirvUcgpg2rZvXmsxXKD5wYGuvg/mapa.jpg)
[Fuente](https://iessonferrerdghaboix.blogspot.com/2014/04/arte-de-mesopotamia.html)
Mesopotamia fue sede de extraordinarias civilizaciones y un centro cultural de gran importancia. Las fuentes médicas escritas más antiguas provienen de Mesopotamia (tablillas de arcilla grabadas con un estilete), escritas en escritura cuneiforme. La más antigua data del tercer milenio y contiene 15 recetas médicas
![hammur 1.jpg](https://steemitimages.com/300x300/https://steemitimages.com/DQmZUbpfPfck6rErZTV5pJCopxxzEyw7cPZ6nXNdsuKQD9b/hammur%201.jpg)
[Fuente](http://plancksconstant.org/blog1/2010/08/the_difference_between_shariah_and_civilized_laws.html)
En 1.902 fue encontrada en Susa una columna de diorita esculpida, que mide 2,50 metros de largo por 1,90 metros de base, grabada en escritura cuneiforme y que hoy se encuentra en el Museo de Louvre: **El Código de Hammurabi**. Redactado con una gran técnica jurídica, no es más que una recopilación de leyes y normas administrativas recogidas por el rey Babilonio Hammurabi (que reinó entre el 1792 – 1750 a.C según la cronología media). Regula entre otras cosas el ejercicio de la medicina (establece las responsabilidades que tienen los médicos en ejercicio, sus honorarios, así como los castigos impuestos por mala praxis). Como ejemplo de sus artículos citaremos los siguientes: - Si un médico ha tratado la herida grave de un hombre con un cuchillo metálico y le ha ocasionado la muerte, se le cortaran las manos. - Si un médico ha tratado una herida grave de un hombre noble y lo ha curado, deberá recibir 10 shekels. - Si trata a un hombre libre, recibirá 5 shekels. - Si cura un esclavo su dueño deberá pagar al médico 2 shekels. - Si un médico le ha causado la muerte a un esclavo de un plebeyo, deberá proporcionarle un nuevo esclavo. En 1.841 se descubre la biblioteca de Asurbanipal en Nínive y en 1.974 la biblioteca del palacio Real de Ebla, encontrándose más de 30.000 tablillas de arcilla. En muchas de ellas de describía la concepción de la salud y la enfermedad, así como las técnicas empleadas por los sacerdotes sanadores.
![tablilla.jpg](https://steemitimages.com/200x200/https://steemitimages.com/DQmakwQHLchny9PLiU2mNqLw84AvyVemK2KtytyntPAf47K/tablilla.jpg)![gilgamesh 2.jpg](https://steemitimages.com/400x400/https://steemitimages.com/DQmQsjPkBdJPVkVg68EKzE5ZvqtGUBp9nTM3f1vbop7CmEi/gilgamesh%202.jpg)
[Fuente imagen de la izquierda](https://alamosdeviento.wordpress.com/2015/10/15/las-tablillas-de-zitchin/) [Fuente imagen de la derecha](http://www.historyshistories.com/mesopotamia-the-epic-of-gilgamesh.html)
Dato curioso es que desde Mesopotamia se ha utilizado la serpiente como símbolo médico. Tiene su origen en la leyenda sumeria del rey Gilgamesh, héroe de muchas leyendas, una de las cuales cuenta que se sumergió en el mar para tomar la planta de la eterna juventud y que a su regreso una serpiente se la roba y se la traga, rejuveneciendo y curando las enfermedades.
![medico.jpg](https://steemitimages.com/300x500/https://steemitimages.com/DQmX2ZnsrQCHaEhSgYBJoBs5bXACAuUvLcsNqw57EM9ApVF/medico.jpg)
[Fuente](http://historiaconminusculas.blogspot.com/2014/03/los-medicos-de-mesopotamia.html)
En Mesopotamia la medicina era una arte sagrado, aprendido en el templo del Dios Marduk (utilizado como escuela de medicina) y sólo practicado por tres categorías de sacerdotes: el **Baru**, el adivinador, quien se ocupaba de realizar el diagnóstico, determinar su causa y establecer un pronóstico (difícil tarea pues debía identificar cuál de los aproximadamente 6.000 posibles demonios era el causante de la enfermedad), el **Ashipu**, que era el que exorcizaba los demonios de la enfermedad y el **Asu**, quien era el médico práctico, el que administraba los medicamentos o intervenía operando. Podían ser ayudados por los Gallulu o barberos o por las Mushenigtu o nodrizas (pero estos no se encontraban a la par de los médicos y eran de casta inferior). El sacerdote o médico era la personalidad más docta de la ciudad, investido de toda autoridad, sabía leer y escribir y conocía sobre ciencia, literatura, religión. Para el diagnóstico de la enfermedad estos sacerdotes utilizaban: 1) El interrogatorio (más bien un examen de conciencia del paciente), que incluía diversas preguntas para determinar el origen del mal, tales como: ¿Has mentido? ¿Has engañado en el peso de la balanza? ¿Has enemistado al padre contra el hijo? ¿O al hijo contra el padre? 2) La adivinación, usando el fuego (empiromancia), el polvo (lecanimancia), los sueños (oniromancia), la astrología (conocían la relación entre los movimientos de las estrellas y la aparición de ciertas enfermedades epidémicas), el vuelo de las aves, la interpretación de las figuras que proyectaba el aceite en el agua o la dirección del humo del incienso. Usaban el examen del hígado o vísceras de animales sacrificados (figura del hígado como fuente de la vida). 3) Los augurios médicos, derivados de la inspección de la expresión del enfermo, de la orina, de la sangre de las sangrías.
![Curador.jpg](https://steemitimages.com/400x700/https://steemitimages.com/DQmesLzZotxkZYRyfyBi1vxSrpUUrtY5nDYMVduhridjb4B/Curador.jpg)
[Fuente](https://historiae2014.wordpress.com/page/79/?iframe=true&preview=true%2F%3Fak_action%3Dreject_mobile)
La concepción terapéutica se basaba en la creencia de que todos los fenómenos se encontraban subordinados a la voluntad de los dioses (castigo divino) y a maleficios producidos por demonios y se intercedía ante ellos para alcanzar la curación (carácter teúrgico de la medicina), atribuyéndole al medicamento propiedades mágicas. Eran utilizadas hasta 250 variedades de plantas medicinales (entre las más comunes la casia, mirra, asafétida, el opio, orégano, tomillo; entre los árboles está el sauce, el peral el pino y la higuera) y sustancias de origen animal (la leche, la piel de serpiente y la coraza de la tortuga) y mineral (sal y el nitrato potásico). Utilizaron el calor, los masajes, la fumigación, los baños medicinales, la curación de heridas, drenaje de abscesos, flebotomías, extracciones dentales e intervenciones quirúrgicas como tratamiento de fracturas, amputaciones y extracción de cataratas. Durante el proceso de curación se invocaba a los dioses a través de las oraciones, se les tributaba sacrificios, todo con la finalidad de congraciar al enfermo con la divinidad y que permitiesen su curación. En otros casos se practicaban exorcismos para librar al paciente del demonio que lo posee.
![Ningizida.jpg](https://steemitimages.com/200x200/https://steemitimages.com/DQmdDYaG3ouM8SCAS8DhBC5KyaeZrr7UrX2U5VduSoZvhwM/Ningizida.jpg)
[Fuente](http://arturjotaef-numancia.blogspot.com/2013/09/deuse-da-caldeia-ningizida-o-deus.html)
Vamos a mencionar algunos de los dioses y demonios realcionados con la salud en Mesopotamia. La diosa Ea era la diosa de la sabiduría y de la medicina, la diosa Gula de los nacimientos, Nin-Azu era un Dios particularmente importante pues era conocido como “el señor de la medicina”. Pero el verdadero sanador fue el Dios Ningizida, representado como una serpiente de 2 cabezas (la que le robó la planta de la vida eterna a Gilgamés). En cuanto a los dioses negativos y demonios, el Dios Tin era el responsable de los dolores de cabeza y Namtaru de los trastornos de garganta, Gallú era el demonio del insomnio, Axaxazu el demonio de la ictericia, el dios de la fiebre y las pestes era Nergal pero el más dañino era “el Séptimo Espíritu”, muy nocivo y agresivo, que reinaba en los días divisibles por 7 (por eso los médicos no curaban en esos días). Los médicos en Mesopotamia dejaron constancia de la existencia de las enfermedades de ojos y oídos, de la piel y venéreas, ictericia y trastornos respiratorios, cardíacos, tumores y artritis. Avanzados en salud pública construyeron comarcas para separar a los leprosos. También adelantaron en el campo de la medicina laboral (justificaban las ausencias en el trabajo por enfermedad) Los medicamentos se administraban a través de supositorios, enemas, o bien a través de la uretra. También se usaban píldoras, polvos y jarabes. Las pócimas eran preparadas de noche, para ser tomadas a la mañana siguiente en ayunas. También usaban emplastos y ungüentos. Otro dato curioso, el primer nombre conocido de un médico es Edinmungi, mencionado en un sello babilónico de alabastro (de más de 4.000 años de antigüedad), que se encuentra en el Museo del Louvre. Se cree que con este sello se firmaban documentos y recetas. El sello tiene representados dos cuchillos rodeados de plantas medicinales. De allí que se diga que la receta médica aparece por primera vez en Mesopotamia.
![astronomia.jpg](https://steemitimages.com/300x400/https://steemitimages.com/DQmNmu9xZzge1K7PrK3nHN2hcX3m38enm1i4fAAxZpfqaBy/astronomia.jpg)
[Fuente](http://www.crystalinks.com/sumercalendars.html)
Lo más importante sin duda es que estas civilizaciones con su grabado en tablillas construyeron un excelente archivo médico, sin contar el resto de los aportes de esta cultura como la invención de la escritura cuneiforme, del arado, el rodillo, el tornillo, la polea, la cuña, la palanca, el plano inclinado, la línea recta, el soplado del vidrio y la cerámica, el sistema sexagesimal, dividieron la circunferencia en 360°, la división del año en 12 meses, de la semana en 7 días y de las hora en 60 minutos, Además codificaron las primeras leyes, desarrollaron el comercio, la aritmética, la astronomía, la astrología, la música, la ingeniería y la arquitectura (con obras que regulaban el curso de los ríos y construcción de grandes torres), escribieron obras literarias como El Poema de la Creación y El Poema de Gilgamés, en fin, fueron civilizaciones con innumerables contribuciones a la humanidad, estableciendo así su legado. Referencias 1) http://www.cervantesvirtual.com/obra/historia-de-la-medicina/ 2) http://www.arabworldbooks.com/articles8.htm 3) https://www.britannica.com/topic/history-of-medicine 4) https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Historia_de_la_medicina 5) http://www.monografias.com/trabajos63/historia-medicina/historia-medicina2.shtml 6) http://www.cardenashistoriamedicina.net/ 7) http://diagnostico-x.blogspot.com/2010/03/la-medicina-en-mesopotamia.html
![Gif español.gif](https://steemitimages.com/DQmZwavykQwGsu7BKWGSBCZHN6VZMMKNoQazRwPnjbKvQBX/Gif%20espa%C3%B1ol.gif)

root_title: Does technology dehumanize us?
body:
It is very common for us to hear that technology dehumanizes us, that is, that it strips us of the characteristics that make us human. But _**what is technology?**_  _**And does it make us less human?**_

We relate the word "Technology" with very new things, usually electronic but it is a very old concept. "Technology" is a word with Greek roots, τεχνολογία, formed by téchnē (τέχνη, art, technique or trade, which can be translated as dexterity) and logía (λογία, the study of something).

Technology is the knowledge applied to the solution of a problem or the improvement of some human capacity. The application of technology allows us, for example: to move further and faster. Apply more force with less effort, see distant things as if they were close and small things see them great, make our voice reach far and listen to what is far away. Remember things we could forget, invent new technologies. Even the most humble and rustic inventions are technological applications. So _**does a pencil, a bicycle, a computer or a video game dehumanize us?**_

![technology-2082642_1280.jpg](https://steemitimages.com/DQmRozPudbkP7W8Vc3YyQWpR5ZYdD38NkGDWy7ur5zNH66w/technology-2082642_1280.jpg)
[Source](https://pixabay.com/es/tecnolog%C3%ADa-informaci%C3%B3n-digitales-2082642/)

First we would have to ask ourselves: _**What do we humans have that other beings have not very developed?**_

To start unlike other animals that adapt to their environment or perish in them, humans are able to adapt the environment to our needs or tastes. _**Is that what makes us human?**_ ... The discussion is philosophical and profound, but we can agree on some characteristics that human beings have developed more:

* **The reasoning,** closely linked to a complex language that allows us to think and communicate abstract ideas. Thanks to language, we can discuss past events, possible futures, even imaginary ones. Language itself is a technology, and writing, which allows us to preserve ideas for future generations, is also a technology.

![Complejidad.jpg](https://steemitimages.com/DQmQ1zpFs9tQSvGCrBPiV4iay6NB4pKHe669R1q2PEiwYAA/Complejidad.jpg)
[Credits of the image](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Complejidad.jpg) _by Jeny Jataco Pérez_

* **The moral and the law.** To agree more or less on what we should do and what we should not do. _**Did you know that one of the first examples of writing history is the Hammurabi code?**_ It is a set of laws written in Babylon around the year 1700 BC.

![5952070337_1d28ed8489_n.jpg](https://steemitimages.com/DQmTjNJh2dGC5riaZL1hWj9brCufC1EFYV7Xid3reH3nxzT/5952070337_1d28ed8489_n.jpg)
[Credits of the image](https://www.flickr.com/photos/gemmerich/5952070337) _by Greg Emmerich_

* **The art.** These activities that allow us to express and share emotions and ideas, such as dance, theater, painting and sculpture, are deeply associated with applications of technology.

![Arte_por_la_Paz_en_el_Museo_Malvinas_(16393723434).jpg](https://steemitimages.com/DQmUzDhFErB4hgNpnGFpoaXo353HjkANfgUQPxkpJmPEtSj/Arte_por_la_Paz_en_el_Museo_Malvinas_(16393723434).jpg)
[Credits of the image](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Arte_por_la_Paz_en_el_Museo_Malvinas_(16393723434).jpg) _by Ministry of Culture of the Argentine Nation_

* **War.** We are the only species that, thanks to the technologies to kill, is capable of extinguishing itself.

![Batalla_de_Murrieta_en_San_Pedro_Abanto_(Segunda_parte_de_la_Guerra_Civil._Anales_desde_1843_hasta_el_fallecimiento_de_don_Alfonso_XII).jpg](https://steemitimages.com/DQmWiGfw6ajRn9QNTc5gXmMcDuq3jtjkxEGnBNdr42z5CTz/Batalla_de_Murrieta_en_San_Pedro_Abanto_(Segunda_parte_de_la_Guerra_Civil._Anales_desde_1843_hasta_el_fallecimiento_de_don_Alfonso_XII).jpg)
[Credits of the image](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Batalla_de_Murrieta_en_San_Pedro_Abanto_(Segunda_parte_de_la_Guerra_Civil._Anales_desde_1843_hasta_el_fallecimiento_de_don_Alfonso_XII).jpg) _University of Seville_

So, it turns out that technology is the one that has humanized us, for better or for worse. But in the end, it is not the technology itself that transforms us, but the use we make of it since it is only capable of enhancing our own abilities.

As the German scientist and writer [Georg Christof Lichtenberg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Georg_Christoph_Lichtenberg) said, _"That had the effect that good books usually have. It made the fools more fools, cleverer the clever ones and the remaining thousands were unharmed. "_

Neither the best word processor can make us good writers, nor the scientific calculator will not make us very intelligent mathematicians, a sophisticated drawing tablet will not make us artists.

![laptop-iphone-notebook-black-and-white-technology-monochrome-1174754-pxhere.com (1).jpg](https://steemitimages.com/DQmV3kzXFrkZGK6Qy8sQH8kjnaAcdFJY6mzycqVDXKyrHgs/laptop-iphone-notebook-black-and-white-technology-monochrome-1174754-pxhere.com%20(1).jpg)
[Source](https://pxhere.com/es/photo/1174754)

Finally, technology allows us to do more effectively, efficiently and accurately what we already know how to do, so the best way to take advantage of technologies is to develop everything we can do without them.

Works of Art (21)
Following the collapse of the Ur III state (ca. 2112–2004 B.C.) at the end of the third millennium B.C., rulers took control of individual cities in southern Mesopotamia and local dynasties formed. Throughout the early second millennium B.C., these local kings vied for power. Dynasties of rulers at Isin, Larsa, and then Babylon gained, in succession, control over large portions of southern Mesopotamia. These cities have given their names to modern chronological periods: the Isin-Larsa period (ca. 2004–1763 B.C.) and the Old Babylonian period (ca. 1894–1595 B.C.). Although modern chronology draws a distinction between these periods in southern Mesopotamia and the Old Assyrian period in the north, city rulers throughout the ancient Near East—including Syria in the west and Elam in the east—maintained regular contact through acts of peace and war.

The first dynasty to reestablish suzerainty over much of southern Mesopotamia came from the city of Isin. These kings gained control of the former Ur III state’s political and religious capitals (Ur in the south and Nippur in the north) and styled themselves after the earlier kings, using titles like “king of Sumer and Akkad” (59.41.86; 59.41.84). Although the kings of Isin never gained control over all the cities of the south, they were included at the end of the Sumerian King List, a Sumerian-language composition that idealizes dynasties going back to antediluvian times as strictly sequential—each having a divinely appointed “turn” (Sumerian: bala)—and never coexisting.

In the early nineteenth century B.C., the city of Larsa, south of Isin and closer to Ur, increased its territorial holding at the expense of other nearby cities. In ca. 1793 B.C., King Rim-Sin (r. ca. 1822–1763 B.C.) conquered Isin and gained control over much of southern Mesopotamia, including the ever-important religious city Nippur. While Rim-Sin has been overshadowed in modern times by other Mesopotamian rulers, he reigned longer than any other king in Mesopotamian history.

Just one year after Rim-Sin’s conquest of Isin, a ruler named Hammurabi (r. ca. 1792–1750 B.C.) ascended the throne of Babylon, a city that lay to the north of Nippur and past the reach of the Isin and Larsa kings. Kings of Babylon had been slowly amassing a small territory in central Mesopotamia, and Hammurabi intensified that effort with stunningly successful results. In some thirty short years, he gained control over the territory of Rim-Sin in the south and dismantled centers of power to the west, north, and east. In addition to being a cunning diplomat and brilliant strategist, Hammurabi also memorialized himself as a pious ruler, builder, and lawmaker—the ideal king. His success transformed Babylon from a city of little importance into the political (and later religious) capital of Mesopotamia.

Hammurabi and many other rulers of the early second millennium B.C. identified themselves as “Amorite” (Akkadian: amurru, Sumerian: mar.tu) kings. Amorite peoples of this period were well integrated into urban society, yet southern Mesopotamian records often portray them as living outside cities in tribal groups. The Epic of Gilgamesh, first written in Akkadian at this time, preserves this attitude toward nonurban peoples in its depiction of the wild man Enkidu—who, according to the story, is a capable defender of flocks but lacks table manners and is in need of a shave. Unfortunately, little information about economically crucial nomadic populations survives in the archaeological record, and our knowledge of the Amorites derives almost solely from the records of those who rose to power in various cities across the ancient Near East.

The creation of the state of Babylon moved the center of power north from that of the old Ur III and Isin-Larsa states and would have been met with aversion by elites in the far south. Nonetheless, Hammurabi’s successors continued to rule southern Mesopotamia for a century and half before their power began to crumble (86.11.111). And even after the sack of Babylon by the Hittite army in 1595 B.C. spelled the end of the Old Babylonian period, the city retained its prominence throughout the second and first millennia B.C.

Art and Culture

An unmatched number of literary works in the historic Sumerian language have survived from the early second millennium B.C. Hymns (86.11.62), myths, epics, letters, and more were copied as part of a scribe’s training (86.11.251) in small schools throughout Mesopotamia. Our earliest knowledge of many Akkadian-language literary works—including the Gilgamesh epic, and the story of a flood survivor—comes also from this time. In many cases, the new Akkadian works are found alongside differently told Sumerian versions. The dynamic mixture of traditions old and new is evident in two ceramic heads in the Museum’s collection (1972.96; 1989.281.7): the large, attentive eyes are reminiscent of worshipper figures set up in temples during the Early Dynastic period (ca. 2900–2350 B.C.).

People of the ancient Near East inhabited a world that was saturated with supernatural powers, and the arts of the Isin-Larsa and Old Babylonian periods show the range of deities available to the individual as sources of protection and well-being (47.1a-h). Cylinder seals with presentation scenes (1987.96.5; 1986.311.39) and terracotta plaques with a variety of figures divine and otherwise (32.39.2) are known in large quantities from these periods. Both cylinder seals and the molds used to make terracotta plaques are negative images capable of producing raised relief images in clay over and over again. Accessible to a broad range of the population, not just the elite, cylinder seals and terracotta plaques maintained a relatively stable repertoire of imagery that spread throughout Mesopotamia and, in the case of the cylinder seals, inspired motifs in Iran (1987.343), Syria (1991.368.5), and Anatolia (1991.368.3).

A lesser-known category of objects dated to this period are the openwork bronzes known in forms both simple (1980.407.3) and complex (1998.31), which are well represented in the Museum’s collection. Slots and circular openings (1984.454.1a,b) as well as rollers (1980.407.1) suggest that textiles, straps, or strings were threaded through the plaques. The exact use of the plaques, however, remains unknown. As materials like textiles do not survive in the archaeological record, we are left to imagine the richness of the objects that included such carefully crafted and decorated bronzes.

Perhaps the most famous work of art from the early second millennium B.C. is the highly polished black basalt stele of the Babylonian king Hammurabi uncovered by archaeologists at Susa in 1902—the so-called Code of Hammurabi. Rulers throughout Mesopotamian history were careful to depict themselves as divinely appointed, just kings (1971.71), and King Hammurabi was no different. Carved on top with an image of the king standing before Shamash, the sun god and god of justice, and beautifully engraved with hundreds of legal decisions, this monumental stele publicly declares Hammurabi’s divinely sanctioned juridical power. Although Shamash appears on the top of the monument, the prologue of the text as well as other works of art attest to the new importance of the god Marduk (86.11.313; 1985.45), who was tied to Babylon as its chief deity for the rest of Babylon’s history.

root_title: Mesopotamian Civilization: Oldest Civilization of the World | World History post no 1
body:
# Mesopotamian Civilization: Oldest Civilization of the World

![](https://secure-media.collegeboard.org/apc/styles/showcase_thumbnail/public/2017-18-ap-histories-update-highlighted-article-thumbnail-800x400_0.jpg?69woAXJV6zpz87go21jmeuIF0xzKQOli&itok=T5YnmNZi) [Image source](https://secure-media.collegeboard.org/apc/styles/showcase_thumbnail/public/2017-18-ap-histories-update-highlighted-article-thumbnail-800x400_0.jpg?69woAXJV6zpz87go21jmeuIF0xzKQOli&itok=T5YnmNZi)



Mesopotamia means 'land between the rivers'. Mesopotamia is the land between the rivers  Tigris and Euphrates.

Mesopotamia comprises four regions : Sumer (Southermost region), Babylonia and Akkad (middle region) and Assyria (Northernmost region).

Hammurabi (C.2100BC), the greatest Babylonia ruler, united the whole of what is now known as Iraq into single kingdom. He gave his people a code of laws. His code covers every aspect of live. His code was based on the law of 'eye for eye' and 'tooth for tooth' i.e., the law of 'tit for tat'.

Hittites, who came from Asia Minor (now Turkey) and destroyed the Babylonian kingdom, were the first to make regular use of horses for war chariots and to make iron implements.

The potter's wheel was perhaps first used in Mesopotamia.
![potter's wheel](http://ak3.picdn.net/shutterstock/videos/16268623/thumb/1.jpg)[Image source](http://ak3.picdn.net/shutterstock/videos/16268623/thumb/1.jpg)

The Mesopotamian were also seem to have been the first to make glass ware.

The Sumerians were the first to evolve a proper system of writing. This system is called cuneiform. Cuneiform script was described by [Henry Rawlinson.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sir_Henry_Rawlinson,_1st_Baronet)

The Mesopotamian system of counting is known as sexagesimal because they count by sixties as we count by tens.

Mesopotamian in mathematics had discovered what was later called the Pythagoras theorem.

In astronomy [Mesopotamian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mesopotamia) made astonishing progress they could calculate length of day and night.

For reference: Lucent's General Knowledge [Book](http://amzn.to/2o9MmNz)

body:
*This is a translation I made of an article written by the greatest Polish mind, the most based politician in Europe, **Mr. Janusz Korwin-Mikke**.
It's going to be about European values.*

![Korwin-bilard.jpg](https://res.cloudinary.com/hpiynhbhq/image/upload/v1518990116/v1cqy1hu0no5azn839zd.jpg)


### European values vs. EU values
The progressives regressed us to the times of slavery - because only under slavery the master can decide instead of a free man.

French presidential candidate Alain Juppe declared that in the European Union welcomed are only those countries which impose so-called "European values" on their citizens. What he means by "European values" and what we should understand as *European values* shall be the topic of this essay.

In Europe there used to be a common codex of values, a legacy of ancient Babilon and Egypt, used by the Jews, the Romans, the Greeks, modified severely by Christianity. It used to be a great civilization. The best one, as it dominated the world. But 150 years ago so-called progressives appeared, that is people who wanted to regress us into the primitive times. And after mere six generations they succeeded - European values were replaced by something different.

So here is the codex:
- The most important principle - the basis of man's sovereignty - "**Volenti non fit iniuria**" ("to a willing person, injury is not done") - has been replaced by the idea of a welfare state, which for people's own good may forbid them swimming, smoking, and order them to wear seat belts and impose social security. And that means it is a revert back to slavery - as only under slavery the master decides instead of a free man.

- In the place of the principle: "**A murderer must be punished by death**", they abolished the death penalty. That means regress to the times before Hammurabi. Only primitive tribes do not know the capital punishment. In vain the great thinker Joseph de Maistre warned: "*If you abolish the death penalty, you will see the whole social order crumble*". And we see that happening with our own eyes.

- The principle: "**Who does not work, may not eat as well**" was replaced by the system of unemployment benefits and food stamps. The grasshopper and the ant story was removed from schools. The result: universal demoralization and flooding of Europe by those who would only eat, but not work.

- The principle that **a family has a head of the family** which makes all the decisions has been replaced by the *dialogue principle*. Thus, perpetual quarrels and child demoralization in families commenced.

- The principle that a **woman has privileges** has been replaced with the *equal rights principle*, therefore women were condemned to daily drudgery. The result was the deterioration of family life and children lost their home. Because a home is a bird's nest to which the male invites the female. When there's no female in the house, there is no home. Only a hull remains.

- The principle that **children belong to family** has been replaced with the principle that *children are the property of the state*. The state decides whether to vaccinate them and against what. The state decides what the school age should be, and what schools are appropriate. It is ok under slavery, for when a slave child grows up, he will toil for the master, not for his parents. The master can, of course, take a child from one family and give it to another, or relocate it to a state-run foster care.

- The principle of **diseducation** was replaced by the principle of *co-education*. This amounts to regression by at least 4000 years. The quality of all-female and all-male schools is much higher than the quality of co-educational schools, but the master wishes his slaves to be dumb and ignorant. If co-education is not enough to dumb down the children, the master introduces integrated schooling, and the retardation of children slowly continues.

- The principle that **boys should be aggressive**, and should partake in fights for the defence of honor, truth, faith, fatherland, women and children - has been driven out. Already in nursery *boys are being mentally castrated*. The master is afraid of slave rebellion, it's obvious. At the same time, the masters are not afraid of an external enemy, because they have agreed on the *principle of fixed and unchanged borders in Europe*.

- The principle that **politics is a matter of men**, has been replaced by the *feminization of politics* - bringing more women into the political game. It's obvious. Women vote for the welfare state, and are less prone to rebellion against the master.

- The principle that **homosexuals live quietly and unbothered** ("Don't ask, don't tell" and general tolerance for harmless deviations) has been replaced by the *nagging imposition of homosexualism as "normalcy"*.

- The principle "**As you make your bed so you must lie**", has been replaced by the principle "*Forewarned is forearmed*". However the whole progress comes from taking risks! For men risk is a normal thing: in the end we are not afraid of riding a bike, speeding on the road, even though we are not paid to do that.

- The principle "**A man should risk his life in defence of his women, children and the values he believes in**" has been replaced by the principle "*Human life is the highest value*". In consequence, the head of Danish Army Labor Union declared during a press conference, that in the case of war, the first duty of a Danish soldier is to display the white flag. And you can't even fire him from the military, because he is protected by the labor law.

- The principle of the **faith in God** has been replaced by the *European Union-mandated atheism*.

- The principle of **hierarchy and authority**, where one man was responsible for decision-making - usually a monarch - has been replaced by *democracy*. In effect, majority rules, and majority consists of more stupid people than wise men. The quality of political life has been lowering dramatically, which can be seen for example during the presidential debates between Trump and Clinton. In practice, everything follows the scenario foreseen by Aristotle: "*Democracy is the rule of donkeys, led by hyenas*". It is a paradox, that a state runs efficiently only when taken over by a reasonable secret service agent like Vladimir Putin...

### 
In conclusion: all the genuine **European values** have been replaced by so-called *values* which are socialistic. That, which is propagated by the European Union, should be considered *anti-civilization*. If European values were the best, then the European Union values, as a reverse, are the worst.

Therefore, please do not be surprised that the West is being colonized by Arabs, Berbers, Chinese, Druze... and Zulus.

Janusz Korwin-Mikke

body:
<center>![](https://steemitimages.com/DQmZenStUF74uCs9ZjdBJgewF94qEAmaUpbyE9tG4h5gs33/image.png)

Nineveh was a prominent Mesopotamian city, located in the current Iraqi town of Tell Kuyunjik, near Mosul. The chronicles of the time indicate that it was inhabited since the VII millennium BC. and that it was one of the largest of the time, because to travel it had to walk for three days.

 

It stood out for its central position in the maritime routes between the Mediterranean and the Indian Ocean and had a large temple dedicated to the goddess Ishtar. It came to have more than 100,000 inhabitants and to have the largest library of antiquity. However, in the year 612 a.C. it was razed and sacked by the troops of the Medes, Scythians and cauldrons, and its ruins were abandoned until in the nineteenth century they were discovered by archaeologists.


BRITISH MUSEUM. Assyrian art in the British Museum in London.
The British Museum is probably one of the four great museums of the world. Only the Metropolitan of New York, the Louvre de Paris and the Hermitage of Saint Petersburg can overshadow it. It is also a global museum, where we can enjoy a lot of works of the various art disciplines from antiquity to contemporary times.

![](https://steemitimages.com/DQmYk5SmCTyYNKyWEz2jymSj3BBBpSa3HyW14PDWRKjz5Qk/image.png)
[reference](https://milviatges.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/08/british-720x400.jpg)

![](https://steemitimages.com/DQmZDVcuXWpRvawkCUw6eVFhAWKYGZFMUmv4f7XZw9D95t1/image.png)
[reference](https://i0.wp.com/farm5.staticflickr.com/4208/35652000482_4cd748f726_z.jpg?resize=480%2C640&ssl=1)


### WHO WERE AND WHERE THE ASYSTEMS LIVED.
______________________
The Assyrian was one of the greatest empires of antiquity. They were located to the north of the territory known like Mesopotamia (in the present Iraq), unlike Babylon, that was located more to the south.

The turbulent history of Mesopotamia has in the Assyrians one of its fundamental actors. The so-called ancient Assyrian Empire dates from 1813 BC. It was the time of King Shamshiadad I. Assyria is defeated by the Babylonians of Hammurabi, who submit her to his empire

After several centuries where the Assyrians are subjected to various Mesopotamian empires, in the fourteenth century BC, King Ashur-uballit I achieved the emancipation of his people and also manages to widen its borders. It is the time of the Assyrian Middle Kingdom. From the 12th century BC, the Assyrians are harassed by several peoples of the area, among them, those known as Peoples of the Sea (like the Mushkin people) or the Arameans. The truth is that the Assyrians often emerge victorious from most battles but it is not a time of annexation.

From the tenth century BC, however, the Assyrians do begin to annex new territories. They are the periods of maximum splendor, what we know as the new Assyrian Empire, and when some of the greatest Assyrian sovereigns reign, such as Ashurnasirpal II, who moved the capital from Assur, to Nimrud. This period lasts at least two centuries, so that in the 8th century BC, the Assyrians are subjecting Phoenicians, Medes, Persians and Israel, among others. It is a vast empire that reaches from Persia to Egypt. The maximum exponent at this time is the king Sargon II, who reigns between 722 and 705 BC, who rises to power after the death of Salmanasar V and it is unclear whether he received the throne via blood or was a usurper.

![](https://steemitimages.com/DQmZHmRfPJQR7Xry8seGzkPgoqLZbwxvVMwGxzTPqxexsPN/image.png)
[reference](https://i1.wp.com/farm5.staticflickr.com/4257/35011283123_8f0869c510_b.jpg?resize=640%2C480&ssl=1)


ART ASIRIO DEL BRITISH MUSEUM
The excavations carried out in the great capitals of the Assyrian empire (Nimrud, Assur, Ninive, Duro Sharrukin), have brought to light, one of the most refined arts of antiquity. Although it has been possible to find the cements of a large number of ziggurats, temples and palaces, what really impresses is the extraordinary decoration of the royal palaces, with an extraordinary iconographic program embodied in the bas-reliefs of the many (hundreds) of panels that were on the walls of the most important rooms of the Assyrian palaces. The adobe and the brick is covered with colored plaster and ceramics, with frosted glass (as we can also see in the Ishtar Gate, which was in Babylon).

LA BIOLOGÌA ANTIGUA

**Los comienzos: dioses, magos, hechiceros**

Puede asombrarnos el hecho de que el origen de la biología como ciencia, la ciencia de la vida por antonomasia, haya que buscarlo en un momento realmente especial de la historia del hombre, cuando nuestros mas remotos antepasados empezaron a considerar el concepto de la muerte y seguramente también el de la vida como algo distinto e importante. Este momento se sitúa como mínimo hace 100.000 años.

https://steemitimages.com/DQmP8DfVDAvt4PWP2KEPFrpNkgMadrQncF2kFVxQXY9DaoW/Prehistoria.jpg

Hasta entonces, los hombres y sus antepasados de otras épocas morían de modo muy similar al de la mayor parte de los otros representantes del mundo animal: abandonados por los compañeros si se encontraban demasiado débiles para proseguir la marcha o para participar en una partida de caza; eran voluntariamente separados del grupo para esperar su fin solos y en un lugar apartado; victimas inconscientes de una catástrofe natural imprevista, del hambre, del ataque de una bestia feroz o de cualquier enfermedad misteriosa. Por consiguiente, la muerte era considerada como un riesgo temible, omnipresente, que era necesario alejar a ser posible evitar. El único medio que el hombre tuvo a sus disposición para poder afrontar serenamente esta problema fue desarrollar una creencia en una vida ultraterrena. Convencido de que su vida debia prolongarse tras la muerte, al venerar a los difuntos, el hombre comenzó a poblar el entorno de fantasmas, a descubrir el mundo de los espiritus del que formaban parte también los animales, las plantas y fenómenos frecuentemente inexplicables que se producian en la naturaleza. En una palabra, incluyo todo lo que formaba parte del entorno del hombre en su vida cotidiana. Los espiritus, aleteando en el espacio, lo vigiliban, lo protegian en la adversidad, pero a veces tambien lo castigaban con desgracias y enfermedades y por ello era precio invocar a los espiritus, respetarlos, honrarrlos cond ones y sacrificios propiciatorios .

THE ANCIENT BIOLOGY

**The beginnings: gods, magicians, sorcerers**

It may surprise us that the origin of biology as a science, the science of life par excellence, must be sought at a truly special moment in the history of man, when our most remote Ancestors began to consider the concept of death and surely also that of life as something different and important. This moment is at least 100,000 years ago.

https://steemitimages.com/DQmP8DfVDAvt4PWP2KEPFrpNkgMadrQncF2kFVxQXY9DaoW/Prehistoria.jpg

Until then, men and their ancestors of other times died in a very similar way to that of most other representatives of the animal world: abandoned by their companions if they were too weak to continue the march or to participate in a hunting party ; they were voluntarily separated from the group to wait for their end alone and in a secluded place; unconscious victims of an unforeseen natural catastrophe, of hunger, of the attack of a ferocious beast or of any mysterious disease. Therefore, death was considered a fearful, omnipresent risk, which needed to be avoided if possible. The only means that man had at his disposal to be able to face this problem serenely was to develop a belief in an unearthly life. Convinced that his life should be prolonged after death, when venerating the dead, man began to populate the ghost environment, to discover the world of the spirits of which were also part animals, plants and frequently unexplained phenomena that were they produced in nature. In a word, I include everything that was part of the environment of man in his daily life. The spirits, fluttering in space, they watch over him, protect him in adversity, but sometimes they also punished him with misfortunes and illnesses and for that reason it was a price to invoke the spirits, respect them, honor them condions and propitiatory sacrifices.

https://steemitimages.com/DQmZnHNKfYWf9jcfUoFQ5fRAR13vKba3BFkYjE48Ew17q42/Chaman.jpg https://steemitimages.com/DQmSsNjY9Vfu6eMrmiMk8wMj7ZoRnEzeg752VKgMGy77CYH/1446326723.jpg https://steemitimages.com/DQmRiQzwxiKF7uW74zBVLR8WgBdkzAuAMkFZ2DCGEC2WSdV/destacada-tlaca.jpg

Therefore, the sorcerer became the most important character in the village; the only representation that we have of a sorcerer was discovered in a wall of the grotto of Trois Freres, in the French Pyrenees: with the face hidden behind a bearded mask, the head crowned by branched deer horns, the hechiecero performs a dance perhaps to ingratiate oneself with the protecting deity of hunting or to drive away the captive spirits whom he believed responsible for some misfortune. From this moment the sorcerer, the one who communicates with the spirits, was also the learned man of the tribe: a little doctor, something surgeon, pharmacist in part, knowledgeable of the secrets hidden in the world of nature. This inevitably led him to expand, day after day, his knowledge of the human body (which sought to restore health), animals (whose organs were sacrificed to the deities) and plants (which collected and mixed in tea and infusions miraculous). https://steemitimages.com/DQmWF1iBCqsCf2Bpe7jUrr8PpXFQdVJw7hxEkccjsh627u5/breuilsorcerer2.jpg We have direct evidence, proportioned in part by fossils, of trepan skulls (perhaps to remove the demon from the head of the patient), of fractured limbs recomposed again with stakes and ligatures, of amputations performed in case of poisoning, of bites or of gangrene due to unhealed wounds. In addition, cave paintings have been found in which the organs of the slaughtered animals are produced with great detail, and it was thought that through this it was possible to obtain a large number of information about the fate of the people and the tribe. https://steemitimages.com/DQmWB9SptyXo7fPjFpPM6YokeKU36MJSXKxkUwLrXPN4DYP/1499323788381.jpg https://steemitimages.com/DQmbt5k6QZED3ost8uRUxcxSfypoR4a3HYSd3z8N9TCEvLH/58db5a0e9f2ed.jpeg As the prehistory of man becomes history despite the influence of superstitions, the knowledge obtained and transmitted in the course of the centuries that make more and more numerous and precise. In ancient Egypt, 2000 years before Jesus Christ, the technique of embalming was so perfect that evidently the practical knowledge of human anatomy must be very advanced, especially (and at least as documented in the papyri documents) in relation to the external anatomy; There was also a lack of knowledge of medicine, of a sometimes surprising modernity, derived from daily experience, such as the advice to supply seeds of poppy to the infant who could not sleep or who did not want to sleep, and also to bottle the body with Cat fat in order to avoid being bitten during sleep by mice. ! [PNp_900.jpg] (https://steemitimages.com/DQmNnh6GYGrY95istwgF5x8MeDK3KNBPQHscMiJsEtzXFQ8/PNp_900.jpg) Around the year 1920 BC, in ancient Babylon, King Hammurabi collected in the codex that bears his name a series of detailed rules related to the medical profession: the doctor was still a priest who, before pronouncing himself, examined the viscera of sacrificed animals or cured with primitive means that were halfway between the magical and the scientific. This situation remained practically unchanged for many centuries among peoples whose civilization was gradually settled: Cretans, Mycenaeans and Greeks, for whom diseases were caused by the darts of the god Apollo suddenly enraged, and it was only possible to attend after appeasing the deity .

root_title: Education for Everyone: An Ancient Idea
body:
![babylonianmathtablet.jpg](https://steemitimages.com/DQmegq31AtRANZaEbpNapCQR1jWrdCo17LJiXY2HToBNubf/babylonianmathtablet.jpg)
Babylonian Math Tablet — Source: Wikipedia, see additional notes at bottom of post.

Education 4000 Years Ago

With the beginning of written language, there also began systematic education which had a purpose beyond survival. But education was not just about learning to read and write symbols that stood for words. Mathematics textbooks have been found in Samaria dating back to 2000 B.C. (Eleanor Robson, Mesopotamian Mathematics, 2100–1600 B.C. (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1999))

The beginnings of school. Schools are probably at least as old as the time of Hammurabi (1792–1750 B.C) It is thought that by this time in history there was a system of schools for the elite, educating priests, scribes, and civil servants. (Murphy Madonna, The History and Philosophy of Education, Voices of Educational Pioneers (New Jersey: Pearson Education, 2006)) There is also evidence to suggest formal schools in China during this same time period. (Ray Huang, A Brief History of Chinese Civilization (New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, 1991))

Around the seventh century B.C., we begin to get a clearer picture of what education was like during this time in China. Formal education was reserved for wealthy men. There were three levels of education. The method was very formal, emphasizing exact memorization of text-like material. The hours were long, the work hard and the teacher often had to use harsh discipline. This is perhaps the first time we see education being used to form the person into what the culture deems good. In this case, the big ideas were teaching tradition, morality, and conformity.

But it was not long before someone rose up, a leader who believed education should be for all, and should not be painful. This leader was Confucius, born in 552 B.C. he brought different ideas to education.

He was the first to set up a sort of private school, where he taught basics to young men of all classes, instead of just the elite.

Confucius believed that teaching was valuable in and of itself.

He believed in cultivating the person by teaching them both practical and moral subjects. (What we would contrast as job training vs. liberal arts.)

He taught using conversation and dialogue instead of focusing only on memorization of texts.

He also taught using maxims or proverbs such as “Learning without thought is labor lost; thought without learning is perilous”.

Confucius expected his students to be the active pursuers of their own learning. He felt that learning not only sharpened the intellect but also the moral character of a person.

He also believed education was central to building a strong society.

So shortly after the rise of language and mathematics, we see a rise in formal education. This education, at least in China, was almost warrior-like, as if survival depended on it. This was an education only for the elite. But it was not long before a movement rose up against such an education, a movement which had as its premise that education is for everyone and if everyone is educated the world will be a better place.

Where are we today? We, like the ancients in China, have a three-level education system, elementary, high school, and college. It is interesting to note that classical education also has three levels, which we will cover in the following posts where we move to an examination of education in ancient Greece. Perhaps our human nature is most at home in a three-level system?

In examining history, we find we are not as special and advanced in our thinking as we often assume. Education for everyone is a very old idea, yet I would argue, because of our self-obsession in the teaching of history, many people think the idea emerged just a few short centuries ago. Also, the idea that an educated society is a better society is not a new enlightenment.

So a harsh education, replaced by a more gentle approach, where the student’s action is perhaps more important than their perfect performance? Will we find this pattern repeated throughout history? How often is education used for enlightenment, sharing amazing ideas for the good of the student and the good of society? How often is it used for conformity, as a tool of manipulation to keep an oppressed society from entering into rebellion? Join me as I explore these questions in the history section of my blog at www.jumpintogenius.com

Picture Notes: A black and white rendition of the Yale Babylonian Collection’s Tablet YBC 7289 (c. 1800–1600 BCE), showing a Babylonian approximation to the square root of 2 (1 24 51 10 w: sexagesimal) in the context of Pythagoras’ Theorem for an isosceles triangle. The tablet also gives an example where one side of the square is 30, and the resulting diagonal is 42 25 35 or 42.4263888… All use should attribute both: mentioning http://www.math.ubc.ca/~cass/Euclid/ybc/ybc.html and the Yale Babylonian Collection as the original holder of the tablet. root_title: Why Isn't There a 13th Floor in some Hotels?
body:
![n-FRIDAY-THE-13TH-628x314.jpg](https://steemitimages.com/DQma4zyCGCkCMDgDACKJHgn4nKBxcTyRNDxzo4Dyhr38c6s/n-FRIDAY-THE-13TH-628x314.jpg)

It's most noticeable in the elevator: in tall buildings, you may see buttons for every floor except 13. For the superstitious, staying, living, or working on the 13th floor can cause a sense of discomfort, sometimes so much so that they switch floors or take their business elsewhere. But according to a 2007 Gallup poll, a whopping 87% of people don't mind staying in a 13th-floor hotel room. 

For years, hoteliers have succumbed to good old-fashioned superstition when they’ve crafted their blueprints. And while the practice of “removing” the 13th floor—or erasing its traces—may seem a bit drastic, it can be partly attributed to a very real phobia. Specifically, triskaidekaphobia, which is an extreme suspicion of the number thirteen. To wit, Friday the 13th gets a bad rap as an unlucky day, but there are also folks who believe it’s no coincidence that Princess Diana died at the 13th pillar of the Pont de l’Alma tunnel, or that the Space Shuttle Columbia disaster occurred on the 113th flight of the shuttle.

## Superstition and 13
Common knowledge has it that fear of the number 13 dates back to one of the earliest written texts -- the Code of Hammurabi. The story goes that the writers of the code left out the 13th law on the list. However, the list has no numbers. Nonetheless, a superstitious fear of the number 13 did crop up. The number 13 may have been bad in early religions. Some say Loki was the 13th Norse god. Judas was the 13th to sit for The Last Supper. However, the superstition was not blatant until the 17th century.

## Elevators
The main area where you will notice the difference when it comes to omission of the 13th floor is in the elevator. You may also notice it in stairwells. These are, for the most part, the only tangible differences. Therefore, hotels are not leaving out the 13th floor. Hotels are simply labeling the floor differently in the few places where these businesses label the levels. According to Otis elevators, up to 85 percent of elevator panels omit the number 13.

root_title: Historia De La Cerveza Y Su Influencia En Los Grandes Momentos De La Humanidad
body:
<center>https://tierradefrontera.es/wp-content/uploads/ingredientes.jpg</center>

Muchas son las facetas por las que pasa la cerveza en su elaboración, sus ingredientes esenciales como el agua, el lúpulo y la cebada se han mantenido por siglos para crear incontables estilos y especialidades cerveceras. Dentro de todo ese tiempo no sólo ha sido reconocida por su sabor, aroma y textura, sino por estar presente en momentos importantes de la humanidad, incluso ha propiciado inventos o mitos que demuestran que esta bebida dorada es todo un misticismo que aún tiene muchos secretos por revelar.
 Es posible que en muchos sucesos de la historia la cerveza sólo haya sido una simple espectadora, una fiel acompañante que supo estar en el momento adecuado –o inadecuado–. Sin embargo, también resulta interesante ver por qué es tan importante para algunas personas y momentos determinados. 

>“La cerveza ha estado presente en momentos importantes de la humanidad, incluso ha propiciado inventos y algunos mitos”.

<center>***La cerveza que convirtió a los nómadas en agricultores***</center>
***
Antes de llegar al periodo neolítico –del 4500 al 4000 a. C.– las civilizaciones humanas se limitaban a ser nómadas, vivían de los frutos que encontraban, cazaban o pescaban. No fue hasta que decidieron cultivar cuando todo cambió. Una revolución comercial y alimentaria se llevó a cabo y la cerveza tomó parte importante, debido a que la cebada era utilizada como un alimento esencial en la dieta de los primeros pobladores asentados del mundo.

<center>https://saboresmodelo.blob.core.windows.net/images/notes/1470773687_57aa39b70e634.jpg</center>

<center>***La cerveza en el Código de Hammurabi***</center>
***
Para la humanidad siempre ha sido de suma importancia mantener intacta la calidad de la cerveza y el Código de Hammurabi da muestra de ello, pues en esta gran piedra que contiene los principios del derecho, el orden y las penas de la antigua Mesopotamia había un espacio que decía: la bebida debe estar regulada. Sólo algunos establecimientos tenían el permiso de comercializarla y si en algún momento se llegaba a degradar y diluir, tal acto era condenado con la pena de muerte.

<center>https://saboresmodelo.blob.core.windows.net/images/notes/1470773576_57aa3948bf5c7.jpg</center>

<center>***Los gustos "especiales" de los babilonios***</center>
***
Se vivían tiempos difíciles –y algo extremos en las leyes– por eso las civilizaciones como los babilonios llevaban al pie de la letra el derecho del Código de Hammurabi; es por eso eran frecuentes las disputas por elaborar la cerveza más pura; sin embargo, si un maestro cervecero no lo hacía bien o simplemente su sabor, aroma y consistencia no convencía a los demás, estos lo ahogaban en su propia bebida. Había muchos catadores pero muy pocos se atrevían a forjarla.

<center>https://saboresmodelo.blob.core.windows.net/images/notes/1470773667_57aa39a3ed296.jpg</center>

>“Es posible que en muchos de los sucesos de la historia la cerveza no haya sido más que una expectante, una fiel acompañante que estuvo en el momento adecuado –o inadecuado– pero sin duda resulta interesante ver por qué es importante para las personas”.

 <center>***Luis Pasteur y su experimento con la cerveza***</center>
***
En los momentos cerveceros no todo es antiguo, ni pegado a leyes extremas, Luis Pasteur es el claro ejemplo, ¿quién era? Fue el inventor de la pasteurización, un procedimiento que consiste en someter un líquido a 80 grados de temperatura para luego enfriarlo, lo que hace se eliminen las bacterias y microorganismos dañinos. Muy común en la leche pero probado por primera vez con una cerveza.

<center>https://saboresmodelo.blob.core.windows.net/images/notes/1470773641_57aa398965fa0.jpg</center>

<center>***La campaña presidencial de Roosvelt y la cerveza***</center>
***
La bebida también ha sido utilizada para fines políticos. A principios de los años treinta en los Estados Unidos, la famosa “ley seca” vivía momentos turbios, estaba apunto de desaparecer y en buena parte con la ayuda de la campaña presidencial de Franklin Delano Roosevelt –creador del “New Deal”–, quien en su búsqueda por alzar a un país de su gran caída económica en 1929, prometió quitar esta norma y para que los ciudadanos estadounidenses gustosos de la cerveza no recurrieran a la clandestinidad.

<center>https://saboresmodelo.blob.core.windows.net/images/notes/1470773469_57aa38dd13df1.jpg</center>

Son incontables los momentos que han marcado a la humanidad, unos son más importante que otros, han influido de manera avasallante o sólo han quedado como un legado cultural, y también están con los que han convivido con la cerveza: curiosos y fascinantes; muestra de que la bebida dorada es ideal en cualquier tiempo y espacio. 
>Fuente https://asobarvenezuela.blogspot.com By Mickey Vera.

In what is considered to be the first beer law in recorded history, the Code of Hammurabi – written by the notoriously cruel Babylonian king named Hammurabi – punished certain violations regarding the drink with death.  

In case you want to read more about this ridiculously harsh Code of Laws, you can read an article I wrote about it for Today I Found Out. 

Back in our wacky fact, during the 2nd Century BC., beer had become the most popular (by far) drink in all Mesopotamia that Hammurabi ruled like a Mafia Boss.  For that reason, several brewers and bar owners tried to make some extra cash by watering down good quality beer, a fact that drove the mad king even madder! 

https://m.popkey.co/a3217e/qxb37.gif

Here Comes The Pain 

If you checked out my article about the Code of Hammurabi, then you already know that messing with the ruthless Babylonian king was probably the very last thing one could do in this lifetime. The man wasn't playing around and as a hardcore "beer lover," he came up with a couple of laws forbidding brewers and bar owners to mix beer with water, or spilling this "divine" drink – even by accident. 

As for the punishment? What else? Death in glorious Hammurabi fashion!!! To be more specific, the violator was drowned in the swill he had created, while the bartenders who spilled beer accidentally had the same fate as well. 

Poor dude...I don't even want to imagine what would have happened to you if Hammurabi was still alive today!

https://media.giphy.com/media/KULwHsy4Lb25G/giphy.gif

root_title: Paris, France Travel Guide
body:
Hі Steemit friends, Today post іѕ аbоut Paris France Travel guide. ![france.PNG](https://steemitimages.com/DQmdDpTWxPJCVBCMk85MqpWqEdZa25rzWDNyAFGP6y6AjP6/france.PNG) Paris, аlѕо knоwn аѕ thе City оf Light, іѕ located іn northern France аnd іѕ home tо approximately 66.9 million people, 2.244 million оf whоm live іn thе dense central city area. Thе French capital іѕ knоwn fоr іtѕ art, fashion, food, design аѕ wеll аѕ thе river Seine. Paris іѕ аlѕо thе mоѕt popular travel destination іn thе world wіth аrоund 32-35 million tourists traveling thеrе еасh year.

History

Paris started аѕ а small Gallic settlement оvеr 2000 years аgо аnd іѕ nоw оnе оf thе world’s major global cities. ![france1.PNG](https://steemitimages.com/DQmTH6Xssu5YCyXqGiE6gsaC9gAedxC8q5nR2Ffo5iHvgXe/france1.PNG) Knоwn аѕ Lutetia, Paris wаѕ conquered bу Julius Caesar іn 52 BC аnd existed аѕ а regional center undеr thе Romans аnd іn thе early Middle Ages. In 987 A.D. Hugh Capet bесаmе king оf France, аnd undеr hіѕ descendants, thе city’s position аѕ thе nation’s capital bесаmе established. Undеr thе leadership оf Etienne Marcel іn 1355-1358, thе people оf Paris declared thеmѕеlvеѕ аn independent commune. Thе storming оf thе Bastille іn 1789 wаѕ thе fіrѕt оf а series оf main actions bу thе Parisian people durіng thе French revolution. In 1871, durіng thе Franco-Russian War, thе city wаѕ undеr siege fоr fоur months untіl France yielded. Durіng World War II thе Germans occupied thе city frоm 1940 tо 1944.

Climate

Aѕ Paris іѕ located іn Western Europe, іt hаѕ а maritime climate. Thе summers аrе warm аnd thе winters cool, but due tо thе proximity оf thе Atlantic Ocean, thе weather doesn’t change dramatically. Durіng thе winter temperature rarely drops bеlоw freezing. Thе bеѕt time tо visit Paris іѕ durіng July аnd August whеn thе average temperature іѕ аrоund 20°C. ![france2.PNG](https://steemitimages.com/DQmQTrmqfWrRLjw9szTYGkgfXdN82159WTndDii37oyb7tj/france2.PNG)

Gеttіng аrоund thе city

Thе bеѕt wау tо gеt аrоund іѕ bу Métro combined wіth ѕоmе walking. Due tо traffic reaching ѕоmе parts оf thе city mау ѕееm impossible bу foot only. Onе wау ticket costs roughly аrоund fеw € аnd аllоwѕ уоu tо reach mоѕt parts оf thе city. Traffic іn Paris іѕ dense аnd renting а car іѕ nоt а viable option. It’s аlwауѕ exciting tо experience thе city bу foot, аnd thеrе аrе numerous walking tours аrоund Paris, whеthеr self-guided оr wіth а touring. Thе city іѕ bеѕt explored bу foot, аnd ѕоmе оf thе mоѕt marvelous memories уоu wіll hаvе оf Paris іѕ walking thrоugh secret fоund places, аnd stopping аt numerous cafés аnd shops. ![france3.PNG](https://steemitimages.com/DQmQ4TbSEkTSknD5AKSBugGtmtnyCw15cuyyYfaxaPXSLAj/france3.PNG) Thеrе іѕ аlѕо thе option tо tаkе а sightseeing boat оn thе river Seine.

Landmarks

Musee du Louvre іѕ thе mоѕt visited museum іn thе world. Thе building іѕ art іn itself, but іnѕіdе уоu wіll find thе world-known Mona Lisa, ancient Egyptian mummies, Code оf Hammurabi аnd оthеr relics. It іѕ located іn 99 rue de Rivoli. ![france4.PNG](https://steemitimages.com/DQmQv5cS7DTyRwqDLbWUSDDHtg2W5hQStN2hGmGurjdWjLM/france4.PNG) Eiffel Tower – Built tо celebrate thе centennial оf French Revolution thе Eiffel Tower іѕ thе mоѕt visited monument іn thе world. It hаѕ bееn ѕееn іn countless movies аnd tv-series. ![france.PNG](https://steemitimages.com/DQmdDpTWxPJCVBCMk85MqpWqEdZa25rzWDNyAFGP6y6AjP6/france.PNG) Musee d’Orsay іѕ а place tо visit fоr аll whо love art; іt іѕ located іn 62, rue de Lille, іn thе fоrmеr railway station оn thе left bank оf thе Seine. It houses аn assortment оf impressionist аnd post-impressionist masterpieces frоm Monet tо Renoir. ![france5.PNG](https://steemitimages.com/DQmUZEKw7JJ5XK66tt7e9iieDQeodghhDYzDzLGiy7osSA6/france5.PNG) Notre Dame Cathedral (Cathedrale de Notre Dame de Paris) іѕ а fine еxаmрlе оf gothic architecture. Nо measure wаѕ spared іn thе building оf а church thаt wоuld reflect thе capital’s prestige. Notre Dame de Paris deserves а place іn anyone’s itinerary. It іѕ located іn 6 place du Parvis, Ile de la Cité. ![france6.PNG](https://steemitimages.com/DQmc17MYyqqctPNxfJiXZhdymeJdHn5hurxMCr31oZegjN6/france6.PNG) Arc de Triomphe – Napoléon Bonaparte commissioned Jean Chalgrin tо design а triumphal arch devoted tо thе glory оf thе imperial army.It honors thоѕе whо fought аnd died durіng thе French Revolutionary аnd thе Napoleonic Wars, wіth thе names оf аll French victories аnd generals inscribed оn іtѕ іnnеr аnd outer surfaces. Beneath іtѕ vault lies thе Tomb оf thе Unknown Soldier frоm World War I. It іѕ located іn Place Charles de Gaulle. ![france7.PNG](https://steemitimages.com/DQmP8tovghK2buS2RZrzcNSascfbB9fu9AwMCryQ7NDW9W6/france7.PNG) Moulin Rouge (Red Mill) іѕ а cabaret built bу Joseph Oller іn 1889. Located іn thе district оf Pigalle іt іѕ bеѕt knоwn аѕ thе birthplace оf modern can-can dance. Nowadays іt іѕ а popular tourist attraction thаt offers musical entertainment tо visitors frоm аll оvеr thе world. ![france8.PNG](https://steemitimages.com/DQmNUB7iitqpwfkJBqheNWp857kvUhBRj9PJsko2up2ktRi/france8.PNG) Sacred Heart Basilica оf Montmartre (Sacre-Coeur) іѕ а church dedicated tо Sacred Heart оf Jesus аnd іѕ located оn Montmartre Hill (35, rue de Chevalier-de-la-Barre). It іѕ аn iconic structure built оf white marble аnd аlѕо thе highest point оf thе city. ![france9.PNG](https://steemitimages.com/DQmb87JyPvkruXriEoexkiNBv1cpXMDEwEXxJ7h7qohHPbT/france9.PNG)

Thіngѕ tо dо

There’s аlwауѕ ѕоmеthіng tо dо іn Paris. Thе bеѕt wау tо experience Paris іѕ tо visit аll thе city’s museums. Thеу саn bе crowded durіng holiday season аnd thе affordable Paris Museum Pass аllоwѕ уоu tо skip lines аnd enter аll museums free оf charge. Thіѕ саn bе uѕеful whеn thе lines extend hundreds оf meters. Thеrе іѕ аlѕо muсh mоrе tо do, thеrе аrе countless possibilities. Paris іѕ packed wіth shops, theatres, аnd events. And gеttіng tо knоw French cuisine іѕ а must.

Safety concerns

Paris іѕ а large but safe city. Mоѕt оf thе crime consists оf pickpocketing аnd scams. Violent crime іѕ uncommon. Pickpockets uѕuаllу hang аrоund crowded tourist areas аnd оn thе route frоm thе airport tо city central. Don’t participate іn аnу card games held bу con artists аrоund Eiffel Tower аnd оn bridges оf River Seine, уоu wіll аlwауѕ lose. Alѕо avoiding illegal taxis іѕ advisable whеrеvеr уоu travel. If уоu lіkе mу Post рlеаѕе dо upvote, resteem wіth friends, аnd write dоwn а comment whаt dо уоu thіng оr аbоut уоur visit tо Paris France. Pictures source: shutterstock images

root_title: Agreeing With Statists For The Wrong Reasons: Conscription
body:
https://i0.wp.com/www.zerothposition.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/02/conscription.jpg?w=550
Conscription of individuals for civil or military service has been practiced since the dawn of statism, and has expanded to include almost all men since the French Revolution. The practice goes by many names: levying, impressment, national service, call-up, and the draft, to name a few. Though many states no longer use it, relying instead upon professional soldiers that enlist voluntarily, most claim a right to resume conscription if they cannot preserve themselves or achieve their foreign policy goals otherwise. This policy is controversial on religious, political, and philosophical grounds. Libertarians object to conscription as a violation of self-ownership, the root of all libertarian philosophy. As Ayn Rand explains,

> “It negates man's fundamental right—the right to life—and establishes the fundamental principle of statism: that a man's life belongs to the state, and the state may claim it by compelling him to sacrifice it in battle.”[1]

According to Ron Paul,

> “Conscription is wrongly associated with patriotism, when it really represents slavery and involuntary servitude.”[2]

The philosophical libertarian case against conscription is [beyond reproach](https://mises.org/library/argumentation-ethics-and-liberty-concise-guide), but the perverse nature of statist systems of governance can make almost any deontologically indefensible policy into a useful strategy for libertarians. Let us see how conscription can backfire on the states that make use of it, and thus why one might agree with statists for the wrong reasons.

By forcing people to engage in an activity, the state provokes feelings of resentment and rebellion. With regard to conscription, this has a variety of effects that undermine the state. First, conscription fuels anti-war movements. Look at the unrest in America during the Vietnam War. Resistance to the draft played a major part in the protest movement, as people burned draft cards, evaded conscription by fleeing to Canada, and attacked draft board offices.[3] Similar examples go all the way back to the time of Hammurabi (r. 1791–1750 BC), when people avoided _ilkum_ (the ancient Babylonian conscription system) by hiring substitutes to fight in their stead, leaving town, or selling property that had ilkum obligations attached to its ownership. These behaviors were outlawed by the Code of Hammurabi, but were widely practiced regardless.[4]

Read the entire article at [ZerothPosition.com](http://www.zerothposition.com/2018/02/10/awsftwr-conscription/)

References:

1. Rand, Ayn (1967). _Capitalism: The Unknown Ideal_. Signet. p. 226.
2. Paul, Ron (2003, Jan. 14). “Conscription Is Slavery”. Antiwar.com
3. Zinn, Howard (2003). _A People’s History of the United States_. HarperCollins Publishers. p. 483–501.
4. Postgate, J.N. (1992). _Early Mesopotamia Society and Economy at the Dawn of History_. Routledge. p. 242–43.
5. McGregor, Andrew James (2006). _A Military History of Modern Egypt: From the Ottoman Conquest to the Ramadan War_. Greenwood Publishing Group. p. 15.

root_title: A World History of Tax Rebellions: An Encyclopedia of Tax Rebels, Revolts, and Riots from Antiquity to the Present
body:
By David. F. Burg
Read preview
Synopsis
A World History of Tax Rebellions is an exhaustive reference source for over 4,300 years of riots, rebellions, protests, and war triggered by abusive taxation and tax collecting systems around the world. Each of the chronologically arranged entries focuses on a specific historical event, analyzing its roots, and socio-economic context.
Excerpt
A World History of Tax Rebellions: An Encyclopedia of Tax Rebels, Revolts, and Riots from Antiquity to the Present provides a historical context to the long struggle against the payment of taxes through examples of tax rebellions throughout world history. Because taxation has often been onerous, and in many cases excessive and cruel, reaction to its enforcement has been consistent, heated, and even violent. Tax revolts or protests date at least to the Later Han dynasty (AD 25-AD 220) in Asia, to the era of Hammurabi (1792-1750 BC) in Babylon, and to the Roman Empire (27 BC-AD 337) in Europe. They persist to the present, as evidenced by Proposition 13 in California and similar subsequent tax reversal initiatives. Many major historic events, such as the Magna Carta, the American Revolution, and the French Revolution of 1789 originated largely as tax revolts. This circumstance alone suggests that tax revolts and tax protests are far more complex than the terms themselves imply-their motivations and ramifications most often go well beyond issues of taxation or even still broader economic considerations.

Thus tax revolts and protests frequently subsume larger economic, political, social, and even religious issues. Taxation often simply provides the ostensible cause for protest and insurrection, especially since taxes afford a ubiquitous, detested, and identifiable target of opposition. The underlying issues motivating the tax protesters may be too diverse, complex, or subtle to evoke the clear focus needed for effective protest; but nearly everyone understands taxes at the most personal and visceral level. Most people also apparently chafe under the perception of taxes as an inescapable burden, irritant, or inequity. As Benjamin Franklin's dictum states, "in this world nothing is certain but death and taxes," and many citizens at certain times may have felt that the possibility of escaping the former actually seemed greater than that for the latter. Taxes, however, are at least corporate and tangible-almost everyone pays them, usually in hard currency or goods-so that disgruntlement and objection come easily.

Franklin's dictum is, of course, based on historic reality. Taxes appear to have coincided with the beginnings of advanced civilization. The ancient states of Persia, Greece, Egypt, and Rome all had sources of revenue based on forms of taxation, ultimately including taxes on real property, sales, and inheritances and customs duties. Unfortunately, official or other documents for many ancient nations or regions have been long since lost to time and decay, so that there is no way of knowing about either their systems of taxation or any possible protests. Furthermore, the extant historic records for many of these ancient states are skimpy, providing incomplete information at best. Consequently, events from the Middle Ages to the present compose the bulk of this book.

A World History of Tax Rebellions: An Encyclopedia of Tax Rebels, Revolts, and Riots from Antiquity to the Present contains entries categorized into different time periods and arranged in chronological order; entries on individuals involved in those revolts; an appendix that lists entries by country or region; a general bibliography; and an analytical index. The entries are global in scope and range in time from antiquity to the present. Included are entries depicting not only openly rebellious events but also orderly protests and forms of avoidance. Avoidance, although perhaps not overtly insurrectionist, has been a significant act of resistance to taxation, especially if it results in changes to laws or policies governing tax systems. Each entry concisely traces the origins of a particular tax revolt

root_title: [Film Review - Prison Movies]
body:
Hai! Steemians. Apa kabar? *T.G.I.F (Thank God It's Friday)*, sebentar lagi *weekend* tiba. Sudah ada film yang ingin ditonton untuk menikmati akhir pekan ini? Sebagai referensi film minggu ini, Dikesempatan kali ini @jun.imaginer akan membahas film-film yang berlatarkan tentang **penjara**. Sebelum kita mulai lebih jauh, sedikit informasi tentang fakta sejarah awal mula berdirinya penjara pertama di dunia.
Penggunaan penjara dapat ditelusuri kembali dari sejarah bangkitnya sebuah negara sebagai bentuk organisasi sosial. Sejalan dengan kemunculan negara, perkembangan bahasa tulisan, yang memungkinkan terciptanya tatanan hukum formal sebagai pedoman resmi bagi masyarakat. Yang paling dikenal dari tatanan hukum awal ini adalah Hukum Hammurabi, yang ditulis di masa Babylonia sekitar tahun 1750 SM. Hukuman atas pelanggaran hukum dalam Hukum Hammurabi hampir secara eksklusif berpusat pada konsep *lex talionis* (hukum pembalasan dendam), di mana orang dihukum sebagai bentuk pembalasan dendam, seringkali dilakukan oleh korban sendiri. Gagasan tentang hukuman sebagai balas dendam atau pembalasan juga dapat ditemukan dalam banyak kode hukum lainnya dari peradaban awal, termasuk kode Sumeria kuno, Manama Dharma Astra di India, Trismegistus Hermes di Mesir, dan Hukum Musa di Israel.[1]
https://img.esteem.ws/rw8c319nec.jpg
[sumber](https://goo.gl/images/xRzwuV) Penjara adalah tempat kedua terakhir yang ingin dihuni seseorang sebelum tidur panjang di kuburan. Kata penjara adalah kata yang umum digunakan untuk menggambarkan sebuah tempat hukuman bagi orang yang dikenakan hukuman pidana. Banyak pula yang menafsirkan kata penjara sebagai tempat bagi orang-orang yang mutlak berdosa sehingga membentuk pandangan bahwa orang- orang yang keluar dari penjara adalah orang-orang yang harus dihindari dalam pergaulan sehari-hari. Masyarakat yang memiliki pemikiran tersebut ada karena tidak pernah merasakan secara langsung manfaat dari keberadaan penjara serta berada di dekat objek penjara tentunya akan selalu dihantui paradigma buruk tentang penjara yang sudah banyak menyebar di masyarakat. Pada akhirnya sering timbul banyak penolakan oleh masyarakat terhadap mantan narapidana yang sudak melewati masa tahanan saat kembali untuk berkehidupan bermasyarakat.[2] Kisah para tahanan yang dikekang kebebasan ruang gerak mereka yang terkadang ditindas dan diperlakukan tidak manusiawi banyak memunculkan kisah menarik dan inspriratif yang kemudian diangkat ke layar lebar oleh para pekerja industri film. Salah satu film kisah nyata (*true story*) inspiratif diantaranya film yang diperankan oleh Denzel Washington dengan judul "The Hurricane" dan "Malcolm X" dan juga film "Mandela : Long Walk to Freedom' yang diperankan oleh Idiris Elba. Selain itu juga banyak film drama-action *blockbuster* meskipun terkesan "*mainstream*", mengisahkan aksi narapidana yang mencari cara untuk kabur dari kungkungan jeruji besi yang selalu menjadi daya tarik penonton untuk disimak. *Gaes*, kalau membicarakan tentang aksi napi yang cerdik dan rumit melarikan diri dari penjara, sudah pasti dong Serial TV Prison Break yang muncul dibenak Steemians. Acara Prison Break dulu sempat pernah mengudara di pertelevisian Indonesia di channel ANTV setiap malam minggu jam pukul 21:00 di tahun 2007 dan kemudian berpindah ke RCTI tahun 2009 yang tayang setiap minggu tengah malam. https://img.esteem.ws/h48yfdrwav.jpg [sumber](https://goo.gl/images/KWGEcV) Lebih jauh lagi, beranjak ke *layar perak*, sebelum membeberkan deretan panjang daftar film terbaik yang mengisi rak *"prison movies"* box office, @jun.imaginer ingin sedikit me-review film berlatarkan penjara yang telah menduduki *peringkat rating tertinggi* di situs IMDB sejak tahun 90an akhir. Film dengan judul **"The Shawshank Redemption"** memimpin dengan rating 9.3 dari hasil jumlah voting user sebanyak 1.907.665 suara.
https://img.esteem.ws/86et6g7lt7.jpg
[sumber](https://goo.gl/images/oyhQ32) The Shawshank Redemption yang rilis 14 Oktober 1994 garapan sutradara Frank Durabont mengangkat cerita dari sorang penulis kawakan Stephen King. Kesanku terhadap film berdurasi 2 jam 22 menit, film ini mengajarkan kita untuk bangkit disaat posisi kita sedang terpuruk jatuh. Melihat bagaimana menyesuaikan situasi dan menikmati setiap momen dari permasalahan yang muncul. Nilai-nilai persahabatan yang dapat kita petik dari tokoh Andy Dufresne (diperankan oleh Tim Robbins) yang mencoba memenangkan hati sesama penghuni lapas Ellis Boyd "Red" Redding yang dimainkan oleh Morgan Freeman serta gerombolan geng napi di penjara Shawshanks. Selain itu, bagaimana dinding beton yang menjulang tinggi dan mendekam dibalik jeruji besi membuat mereka makin dekat dan peduli satu sama lain seperti layaknya keluarga. Selain pesan moral dari film ini, Tim Robbins memberikan salah satu pertunjukan terbaik yang pernah ada. Dia menginspirasi, cerdas dan terutama sifatnya yang *positif thinking*. Tokoh Andy Dufresne yang didakwa bersalah karena membunuh istri dan selingkuhan istrinya. Mendekam di penjara dari dijatuhi hukuman seumur hidup tidak membuatnya putus harapan. Dituntun dengan narasi "suara tuhan" dari Morgan Freeman, Freeman memberikan performa terbaik sepanjang karirnya sebagai tokoh kharismatik dipanggil "Red". Saat tidak ada yang tersisa dari Andy selain harapan. Dia menyibukkan dirinya dengan hal yang positif, seperti melubangi dinding sel tahanan dengan palu batu selama 19 tahun lamanya.
